content:
\>\>\>Why the necessity for this tyranny?   
  
Suppose you want to collaborate on a report (or similar long document) with a subcontractor who doesn't have your fonts.   
   
What do you do, lose all your formatting when you get the document back?   
   
\>\>\>One problem is that the MS core fonts are no longer freely downloadable.   
   
I think they are, just not from Microsoft's site. As I recall, the EULA allowed redistribution, and this is still exploited legally by some individuals.   
   
Oh, here ya go (thanks, google):   
   
 [http://corefonts.sourceforge.net/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043852/http:/corefonts.sourceforge.net/)

\>Suppose you want to collaborate on a report (or similar long document) with a subcontractor who doesn't have your fonts.   
   
\>What do you do, lose all your formatting when you get the document back?   
   
One doesn't collaborate with subcontractors, one hires them.   
Make it a stipulation of their contract that they obtain a licence for the fonts/software you intend to use, and they can build the cost of that into their bill to you.   
   
Otherwise, it is an arrogance on the part of the contractor to impose its corporate fonts on the subcontractor.   
   
If the contractor choses not to, and uses Arial or equivalent, it is less expensive, but less of a distinctive corporate branding. You get what you pay for (unless you have sufficient clout to bully your subcontractors into licensing your corporate fonts).

\>What do you think?   
   
Gerald, part of the risk of going into business is that times change, and one will have invested money in something that becomes obsolete, either through a changing of fashion, the economy, or technology. There is no such thing as a right to a continuing ROI.   
   
Eric Gill is long gone. Let's support contemporary type culture, as an expression of the present day and age, by licensing contemporary fonts.   
   
I'm not saying there isn't a place for the classics, but they should not dominate the scene the way they do.   
   
Interesting that you mention Gill Sans, as this was one of the typefaces that Adobe gave away on an Illustrator CD in the mid 90s. Millions (I assume) of free copies. Well, that's one way to prime a market. But it kind of pulled the rug out from underneath Cronos.   
   
Gill Sans is a 1930s typeface. The bowl of the a has the bulbous look of the baby carriages of that era. To me, it looks totally incongruous today. However, it made a valuable contribution to the living tradition of type design: if art directors want to choose a typeface that, because of its structure and proportions, works in a similar manner, they should use the present day "equivalents", such as Cronos, Scala/Seria Sans, Bliss (good choice, m-ga), Agenda, Eureka Sans, etc. That would make our business more vital and sophisticated than if everyone just uses poor old Gill.

Nick,   
   
Adobe were GIVIG AWAY Illustrator!? When was that? I thought Illustrator always cost money, and obviously, the customer also paid (among others) for the fonts included. They were not free copies, but of course, they were greatly reduced vs. the fonts sold separately.   
   
I can't agree that Gill Sans is "poor old". I'd rather say it's "great old". I myself prefer a good typeface over a new typeface. Among the designs you listed, I can't find a single one that would be superior to Gill Sans. To me, the first sanserif for years that can stand up against Gill Sans is Frantisek Storm's Sebastian:   
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/sebastian/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150218043852/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/storm/sebastian/)   
   
It's similarly sophisticated without being artificially elaborate.   
   
If I were to choose between Gill and Cronos, I'd choose Gill -- even if both were designed at the same time. The same for Agenda vs. Gill etc. I won't even compare Scala Sans, Bliss or Eureka Sans. They're nice but have by no means the touch of eternity and universality that Gill Sans has. I'd say, Gill Sans is still better.   
   
Adam

I'm happy that our Alfon and Giacomo are on your list. They are both OpenType. As to your indecision regarding ClearviewOne because of the price, why don't you email me directly and perhaps we can work out a discount seeing as you are thinking of buying two of our families.

you're kidding aren't you? There ain't no such thing as a free lunch -- it's the first thing you learn at a "elements of economy" class at high school. At least, at a Polish high school over here.   
   
"Buy one get one free" is a marketing gag. If you believe in such nonsense -- well, I'm sorry.

When fonts are bundled with software, they are simply part of the package. No part of the package is 'free': you pay for the whole package. The fonts are likely discounted in that the whole software package may cost less than it would to license the fonts by themselves, but they are no more free than InDesign and Photoshop are free when they are bundled with Illustrator in the Creative Suite. You are licensing a software package that includes multiple parts.

\> **_Many of the users choose classic typefaces because they lack the hability to evaluate type._**   
   
I don't get it, what's wrong with classic typefaces? Is it inconceivable that someone would choose a classic typeface just because they like it or because they prefer it to another, which happens to be contemporary (which I am assuming is the opposite of how you are using the term 'classic')?   
   
To paraphrase Tina Turner: What's age got to do with it?
I think H

\> **_many people choose a classic type like Bembo or Gill Sans because it is 'proven'._**   
   
Ok, that makes sense, but what's wrong with it? Isn't it in many ways a best-case scenario for the casual type user to choose proven combinations rather than risk disaster on the thin ice of untested type mix-and-match?   
   
Unless you know exactly what you're doing, that tempting pairing of, say, Wilhelm Klingspor Gotisch and Neutraface might just blow the bosses mind.   
   
\> **_Choosing a newer, unproven typeface requires a greater degree of typographic discernment._**   
   
Of course.   
   
I'm tempted to say that is exactly why this is best left to type aficionados with ample time, passion and a professional eye, but then that is an awfully elitist point of view and anyway, we all know you can't save anyone from themselves.   
   
Maybe if folks go for the safe and tested option it just shows that they are aware that type is full of pitfalls. That seems fair enough.

I don't think there is anything wrong with someone who has the job of choosing a typeface, for whatever purpose, falling back on a reliable and proven classic in the absence of the necessary experience and discernment required to be more daring. It is prudent. But if that person has to choose another typeface for another project next week, and again after that, and if choosing a typeface becomes part of that person's job description, e.g. if he is a graphic designer or art director, I think there is something wrong with choosing those reliable and proven typefaces year after year, for every purpose. It suggests a failure to develop discernment and to build on experience.

_But "mood" is the only justification for making new type._   
   
This is probably true for display type, but in my experience most new text type development is driven by economic and technical requirements and what might be termed 'appropriateness to purpose'. We need new types because we keep producing new texts, and new kinds of text. This has always been the case, and it is worthwhile to map major developments in the history of type design to developments in literature. 'Mood' may be one of the factors that makes a typeface appropriate to a text, but it is certainly not the only one.   
   
Of course, there is also the question of whether one needs to justify the making of new type -- or a new chair design, or a new piece of architecture -- other than by variety and by the human need to create new forms.
